result.execSummary:
The defendant was charged with both OWI (3rd) and Operating w/ PAC (3rd) [Modifiers: Penalty - Operating While under the Influence (2nd Offense)]. The defendant was found guilty of OWI (3rd) and the other charge, Operating w/ PAC (3rd) [Modifiers: Penalty - Operating While under the Influence (2nd Offense)] was dismissed by the court.

  • Bryan D Anderson was found guilty of OWI (3rd), an unclassified misdemeanor, Wisconsin Statutes 346.63(1)(a).

Notice to employers: It may be a violation of state law to discriminate against a job applicant because of an arrest or conviction record. Generally speaking, an employer may refuse to hire an applicant on the basis of a conviction only if the circumstances of the conviction substantially relate to the particular job. For more information, see Wisconsin Statute 111.335 and the Department of Workforce Development's publication, Arrest and Conviction Records under the Law.

supervisions.notes: Fine and court costs are to be paid as follows:  $100 due on or before 6-1-16 and then $100 due by the 1st of each month thereafter until paid in full.  Failure to pay in full by the due date will result in serving up to 30 days jail.
Must submit a DNA sample to the Jackson County Jail on May 5, 2016 and pay the surcharge.
Remanded to jail immediately after sentencing.  Credit for 5 days jail served.

Per Statute 343.301(g) your operating privileges for operation of Class D vehicles will require that vehicles owned and/or driven by you be equipped with an ignition interlock device.  Must install a mandatory Ignition Interlock Device when defendant obtains an occupational license or regular license.  There is a $50 ignition interlock surcharge imposed.
Must attend and successfully complete an alcohol assessment and a driver safety plan.  You must also comply with any recommendations.

chargeModifiers.descr: Penalty - Operating While under the Influence (2nd Offense)

records.descr: Order for intox driver assessment and safety plan

records.addlTxt: Associated with Charge #1

Defendant Bryan D Anderson in court with attorney Jessie Gwynn Weber.  Gerald R. Fox appeared for the State of Wisconsin.  An amended complaint was filed. Will plea to Count 1 with a joint recommendation of$2042 fine including costs, 95 days in jail, EMP or Huber, IID, DL rev, AA & DSP.  Defense requests the mininimum of 1 year for the IID requirement.  Court reviews charge/potential penalties with defendant.  He understands.  Pleads guilty to amended Count 1.  Court reviews elements of charge.  Defendant admits to prior convictions.  Reviews plea questionnaire/waiver of rights with defendant.  Defensen stipulates to factual basis for the plea today.  Court finds plea is made FVI made/wiaves rights.  Court finds guilty of Count 1 - OWI 3rd, PAC is dismissed.  Court adopts the joint recommendation of a fine including costs of $2502, IID 27 months, DL revoked 27 months
from Attorney Weber
Plea/sentencing hearing on May 2, 2016 at 01:30 pm.
From defense requesting the STC for 2-22 be adjourned (already rescheduled)
Status conference at 04-04-2016 03:00 pm

Pre-trial conference at 02-03-2016 10:00 am.
Status conference at 02-22-2016 03:00 pm.

Defendant shall not consume any alcohol unless a physician states in writing that the defendant is alcohol dependent and complete withdrawal could endanger the defendant's health or life. In this case a doctor's excuse must be submitted to the Jackson County Clerk of Court or the Jackson County Jail within 48 hours of the bond being signed. Not to enter into any bars, taverns, liquor stores, liquor department of grocery stores, bar areas of restaurants, or where available for consumption on the premises where the defendant is located except for employment purposes as "Drain Works" only.  The defendant may submit to a PBT if requested by any law enforcement officer.

Defendant shall not consume any alcohol unless a physician states in writing that the defendant is alcohol dependent and complete withdrawal could endanger the defendant's health or life. In this case a doctor's excuse must be submitted to the Jackson County Clerk of Court or the Jackson County Jail within 48 hours of the bond being signed. Not to enter into any bars, taverns, liquor stores, liquor department of grocery stores, bar areas of restaurants, or where available for consumption on the premises where the defendant is located except for employment purposes as "Drain Works" only.  The defendant may submit to a PBT if requested by any law enforcement officer.

Attorney Weber requests modification.  May be where alcohol is sold or served for employment purposes as "Drain Works" only.   As far as PBT condition.  Only to submit to PBT testing if requested by any law enforcement officer.

Court questioned defendant on his understanding of the waiver of time limits.  Defendant stated he understood.  Court found that the defendant knowingly and intelligently waived time limits.  PTC set for 2/3 and STC 2/22 at 3 pm

records.addlTxt: ADA Melissa Inlow appears for the State.  Defendant appeared in person and with Attorney Weber.

Defendant shall not consume any alcohol unless a physician states in writing that the defendant is alcohol dependent and complete withdrawal could endanger the defendant's health or life. In this case a doctor's excuse must be submitted to the Jackson County Clerk of Court or the Jackson County Jail within 48 hours of the bond being signed. Not to enter into any bars, taverns, liquor stores, liquor department of grocery stores, bar areas of restaurants, or where available for consumption on the premises where the defendant is located.  As a condition of your release, you must be available 24 hours per day, 7 days a week to submit to testing for alcohol when requested by a law enforcement officer or your probation agent. The defendant may submit to an alcohol test at the Jackson County Sheriff's Office or submit to a PBT by a law enforcement officer. Upon request, the defendant shall appear for and submit to testing within two (2) hours of the official's request.
Defendant appeared by video from the Jackson County Jail.

ADA Melissa Inlow appears for the State.  Defendant appeared by video from the Jackson County Jail.  Court recited the charges and possible penalties contained in the complaint.  Defendant said he understood.  Court advised the defendant to contact SPD.  He is trying to contact his attorney.  Bond set.  AIA set for 1/11/16 at 9 am.
Adjourned initial appearance at 01-11-2016 09:00 am

Defendant shall not consume any alcohol unless a physician states in writing that the defendant is alcohol dependent and complete withdrawal could endanger the defendant's health or life. In this case a doctor's excuse must be submitted to the Jackson County Clerk of Court or the Jackson County Jail within 48 hours of the bond being signed. Not to enter into any bars, taverns, liquor stores, liquor department of grocery stores, bar areas of restaurants, or where available for consumption on the premises where the defendant is located.  As a condition of your release, you must be available 24 hours per day, 7 days a week to submit to testing for alcohol when requested by a law enforcement officer or your probation agent. The defendant may submit to an alcohol test at the Jackson County Sheriff's Office or submit to a PBT by a law enforcement officer. Upon request, the defendant shall appear for and submit to testing within two (2) hours of the official's request.
